name: Tobacco mosaic virus
summary: Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) is a plant pathogenic virus that causes mosaic-like symptoms on a wide range of plant species, including tobacco, tomatoes, peppers, and many ornamental plants. It is one of the most studied plant viruses and was the first virus to be discovered.

cause_of_disease.describe: The virus is primarily spread through mechanical transmission. This can happen via contaminated tools, hands, clothing, or direct contact with infected plants.
In some plant species, TMV can be transmitted through infected seeds, leading to the development of symptoms in seedlings.
TMV is highly stable and can remain infectious in plant debris, contaminated soil, or on surfaces for extended periods, posing a continual infection risk.

steps: Select and plant TMV-resistant crop varieties if available.
Consult with local agricultural extensions for specific resistant strains.
Regularly disinfect tools, equipment, and hands when handling plants.
Avoid the transfer of plant sap between plants by careful handling.

solution.solution: Crop rotation and removal of infected plants
steps: Rotate crops to prevent the buildup of the virus in the soil.
Promptly remove and destroy infected plants to reduce sources of infection.

tips: Avoid smoking or using tobacco products near susceptible plants to prevent potential transmission.
Control weeds to reduce potential reservoirs of the virus in and around plantings.
Educate workers and visitors about the importance of not handling plants unnecessarily to minimize the risk of mechanical transmission.
